text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 1     Guidance note on the role of Cash and Voucher Assistance to reduce financial barriers in the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, in countries
label: BODY

text: targeted by the Global Humanitarian Response Plan COVID-19.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN CASH AND
label: HH1

text: VOUCHER ASSISTANCE
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Humanitarian actors have made considerable progress in promoting data responsibility in cash
label: BODY

text: and voucher assistance (CVA) in recent years. However, gaps remain between global frameworks
label: BODY

text: for data responsibility and their practical application in the delivery of CVA.
label: BODY

text: •	 There are many resources available on data protection in CVA programmes, but guidance and
label: BODY

text: practical tools are lacking for the responsible management of sensitive non-personal data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common data-related benefits in CVA include: (i) improved understanding of beneficiary
label: BODY

text: priorities, needs and preferences; (ii) improved targeting of assistance, including deduplication
label: BODY

text: of beneficiary lists; (iii) increased efficiency and effectiveness of different delivery mechanisms;
label: BODY

text: and (iv) enhanced transparency and accountability.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common data-related risks in CVA include: (i) exposure of sensitive data that could lead to
label: BODY

text: various forms of harm for affected people and/or humanitarian staff; (ii) breaches in data
label: BODY

text: protection, data privacy and data security; (iii) potential misuse of data for non-humanitarian
label: BODY

text: purposes by third parties; and (iv) loss of trust between affected people and humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations can improve data responsibility in CVA by taking the following
label: BODY

text: actions: (i) mapping the CVA data ecosystem; (ii) establishing an information sharing protocol
label: BODY

text: specific to CVA programmes; (iii) establishing data sharing agreements for the exchange of
label: BODY

text: personal data; (iv) conducting data impact assessments for all CVA interventions; (v) introducing
label: BODY

text: data incident management procedures; and (vi) tracking issues and progress on data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in CVA through coordination structures.
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: As digital tools become more central in the delivery of cash and voucher assistance (CVA), humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations, financial service providers, and other stakeholders gather, store, use and share increasingly
label: BODY

text: large volumes of data. These trends have been accelerated in the response to COVID-19, for which cash
label: BODY

text: actors have scaled up and adapted their CVA programmes in line with the particular challenges posed by
label: BODY

text: the pandemic, with a preference towards contactless electronic or mobile payments to reduce the risk of
label: BODY

text: transmission.1
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 2    CaLP, 2020. State of the World’s Cash Report 2020.
label: BODY

text: 3   Ibid.
label: BODY

text: 4   These include efforts through the Grand Bargain Cash workstream working group on Cash and Risk, the Cash Learning Partnership (CaLP), the
label: BODY

text: Common Cash Delivery Network, and the UN Common Cash Statement, among others.
label: BODY

text: 5   International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and Privacy International, 2018. The humanitarian metadata problem: “Doing no harm” in the
label: BODY

text: digital era.
label: BODY

text: 6  For more on data protection in cash and voucher assistance, see CaLP’s Protecting Beneficiary Privacy, the Common Cash Delivery (CCD) Network’s
label: BODY

text: Protecting personal data and privacy in field work: A guide for data sharing between humanitarian organizations, and the ICRC Handbook on
label: BODY

text: Data Protection in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: According to the 2020 State of the World’s Cash report, perceptions of digital and data management risks
label: BODY

text: have also increased in prominence in recent years.2 The following concerns have been acknowledged in
label: BODY

text: various CVA fora3: (i) there is a significant gap in practical resources to help practitioners marry the ethical
label: BODY

text: standards contained in data responsibility policies with the day-to-day pressure to deliver programmes; (ii)
label: BODY

text: there are no mechanisms in place to enable collective sharing of, and learning from, critical data incident
label: BODY

text: management cases; and (iii) lower risk appetite in CVA, partially due to Anti-Money-Laundering/ Counter-
label: BODY

text: Terrorism measures and the political economy of cash, which extends into the data management space.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian actors have made considerable progress in promoting data responsibility in CVA. A range
label: BODY

text: of initiatives4 aim to ensure the protection of aid recipients and support more efficient, collaborative and
label: BODY

text: data-driven ways of working. Bilateral and multilateral engagements between humanitarian organizations,
label: BODY

text: including global data sharing agreements and joint programme delivery strategies, complement these
label: BODY

text: collective efforts.
label: BODY

text: Nevertheless, gaps remain between global frameworks for data responsibility and their practical application
label: BODY

text: in the delivery of CVA. This guidance note aims to help fill these gaps by offering an overview of the common
label: BODY

text: data-related benefits and risks encountered by cash actors. It provides a set of actions that organizations
label: BODY

text: can take to improve data responsibility in the delivery of cash and voucher assistance.
label: BODY

text: DATA MANAGEMENT FOR CASH AND VOUCHER ASSISTANCE
label: HH1

text: CVA requires the collection of personal and non-personal data that would be considered sensitive in
label: BODY

text: most humanitarian settings. Personal data commonly collected in CVA programmes includes national ID
label: BODY

text: numbers, phone numbers and addresses, family members’ names, personal bank details, and biometric
label: BODY

text: data, among others. Common non-personal data in CVA programmes includes microdata from surveys and
label: BODY

text: needs assessments, demographically identifiable information about different groups receiving assistance,
label: BODY

text: location data for CVA distribution points, and anonymized and/or aggregated community feedback data,
label: BODY

text: among others. The delivery of CVA also generates new forms of metadata5 that humanitarian organizations
label: BODY

text: previously have not had to manage, such as data about transactions with different financial service
label: BODY

text: providers and affected populations’ spending or consumption patterns.
label: BODY

text: Unlike other areas of humanitarian assistance, CVA involves a particularly wide and diverse range of actors.
label: BODY

text: The complexity of the flow of data between humanitarian organizations and different partners involved in
label: BODY

text: the delivery of CVA gives rise to data protection issues and other concerns, outlined in more detail below.
label: BODY

text: Different standards for data responsibility are applied in CVA programmes across organizations and
label: BODY

text: contexts. This is due to (i) varying levels of familiarity with existing data responsibility guidance and related
label: BODY

text: capacity gaps among programme staff and (ii) evolving data risks related to new delivery mechanisms
label: BODY

text: and partnership models for CVA. Existing guidance6 is primarily focused on the safe management and
label: BODY

text: protection of personal data, and does not fully address concerns related to non-personal data that is
label: BODY

text: sensitive in many contexts and requires robust protections.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: Practical Guidance for the Cash Community: CaLP’s Data Responsibility Toolkit
label: BODY

text: CaLP’s Data Responsibility Toolkit offers detailed guidance on data responsibility in cash and voucher
label: BODY

text: assistance. The toolkit aims to better reflect the complexity of partner relations, operational delivery
label: BODY

text: models and associated data flows. It also aims to address elements of remote data collection that
label: BODY

text: emerged in early 2020 in light of COVID-19.
label: BODY

text: The toolkit highlights the need for an ecosystem approach and power analysis among those who
label: BODY

text: collect, use and share data from CVA recipients. It also notes the need for contextualization, creativity,
label: BODY

text: capacity and collaboration among CVA actors and across organizational teams to ensure better
label: BODY

text: protection of data.
label: BODY

text: The toolkit includes in-depth consideration of some of the tensions among different actors with
label: BODY

text: regard to data, as well as orientation on data sharing, relationships between data controllers and
label: BODY

text: data processors, privacy impact assessments, lawful bases for data collection (including consent and
label: BODY

text: legitimate interests), preparing for possible critical data incidents or breaches, and communication
label: BODY

text: with affected populations about data collection and processing.
label: BODY

text: It is structured around the different steps of a data lifecycle typical to CVA programmes and covers
label: BODY

text: both personal and non-personal data, while also incorporating new legal requirements stemming
label: BODY

text: from the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation.
label: BODY

text: DATA-RELATED BENEFITS AND RISKS IN CASH AND VOUCHER ASSISTANCE
label: HH1

text: Data responsibility requires a clear understanding of both the benefits and the risks associated with data
label: BODY

text: management. While they may vary from one setting to the next, there are commonly recognized data-
label: BODY

text: related benefits and risks within the CVA community.
label: BODY

text: Benefits in CVA include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Improved understanding of beneficiary priorities, needs and preferences.
label: BODY

text: •	 Improved targeting of assistance, including deduplication of beneficiary lists.
label: BODY

text: •	 Increased efficiency and effectiveness of different delivery mechanisms.
label: BODY

text: •	 Enhanced transparency and accountability.
label: BODY

text: Risks in CVA include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Exposure of sensitive data that could lead to various forms of harm for affected people and/or
label: BODY

text: humanitarian staff.
label: BODY

text: •	 Breaches in data protection, data privacy and data security.
label: BODY

text: •	 Potential misuse of data for non-humanitarian purposes by third parties.
label: BODY

text: •	 Loss of trust between affected people and humanitarian organizations.
label: BODY

text: Know Your Customer (KYC) regulations
label: BODY

text: Know Your Customer regulations, also known as customer due diligence, are designed to combat money laundering,
label: BODY

text: terrorist financing and other related threats to the financial system. They refer to the ID checks that financial
label: BODY

text: institutions perform to comply with national financial regulations. While some humanitarian agencies are not directly
label: BODY

text: subject to KYC regulations, the financial service providers that they partner with are. As such, these regulations have
label: BODY

text: a direct impact on the responsible management of data generated and shared for cash and voucher assistance. KYC
label: BODY

text: requirements are set at the national level and may vary depending upon specific criteria.
label: BODY

text: For more on KYC in humanitarian cash and voucher assistance, see elan's Tip Sheet on KYC Regulations and UNHCR
label: BODY

text: and World Vision’s Know Your Customer Standards and Privacy Recommendations for Cash Transfers.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 7    See for example the Minimum Core Assistance Delivery Dataset for Affected Populations.
label: BODY

text: 8    OCHA, 2019. Working Draft Data Responsibility Guidelines, 55-62.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN CASH AND
label: HH1

text: VOUCHER ASSISTANCE
label: HH1

text: Data responsibility requires the implementation of principled actions at different levels of a humanitarian
label: BODY

text: response. This includes actions to ensure data protection and data security, as well as strategies to
label: BODY

text: minimize risks while maximizing benefits of data management.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’), CaLP and NORCAP/Norwegian Refugee Council
label: BODY

text: recommend following actions to improve data responsibility in the delivery of cash and voucher assistance:
label: BODY

text: •	 Map the CVA data ecosystem
label: HH1

text: •	 Establish an information sharing protocol specific to CVA programmes
label: HH1

text: •	 Establish data sharing agreements for the exchange of personal data
label: HH1

text: •	 Conduct data impact assessments for all CVA interventions
label: HH1

text: •	 Introduce data incident management procedures
label: HH1

text: •	 Track issues and progress on data responsibility in CVA through coordination structures
label: HH1

text: The table below provides a description of these actions and references to additional guidance and
label: BODY

text: templates from different humanitarian organizations where available.
label: BODY

text: Action
label: BODY

text: Map the CVA data
label: HH1

text: ecosystem
label: BODY

text: A data ecosystem map helps identify data gaps and possible duplications,
label: BODY

text: and enables prioritization and strategic decision-making on responsible data
label: BODY

text: management. It provides a summary of major data management activities,
label: BODY

text: including the scale, scope and types of data being processed, the stakeholders
label: BODY

text: involved, the data flows between different actors, and processes and platforms
label: BODY

text: in use in the delivery of CVA in a given context. The data ecosystem mapping
label: BODY

text: exercise should be completed and subsequently updated on an annual basis by
label: BODY

text: the Cash Working Group (CWG) in collaboration with their partners.
label: BODY

text: Description
label: BODY

text: An information sharing protocol (ISP) serves as the foundation for a collective
label: BODY

text: approach to responsible data and information exchange. The ISP sets out terms
label: BODY

text: that all humanitarian organizations and third-party service providers involved
label: BODY

text: in delivering CVA agree to uphold. It should complement any pre-existing
label: BODY

text: bilateral data sharing agreements (see below), align with applicable Know Your
label: BODY

text: Customer (KYC) standards, and include key elements such as a data sensitivity
label: BODY

text: classification and a data retention and destruction schedule. An ISP may also
label: BODY

text: specify a minimum core dataset7 to facilitate the provision of cash assistance in
label: BODY

text: a particular context. A template ISP8 is included in the OCHA Data Responsibility
label: BODY

text: Guidelines. The development of an ISP specific to CVA programming should
label: BODY

text: be completed as a collective exercise led by the CWG.
label: BODY

text: A data sharing agreement (DSA) establishes the terms and conditions that
label: BODY

text: govern the sharing of personal data. It is primarily used for data sharing
label: BODY

text: between two parties and is typically established at the country level. In
label: BODY

text: accordance with data protection frameworks, signing a DSA is required for the
label: BODY

text: sharing of personal data. In CVA programmes, DSAs or similar agreements are
label: BODY

text: required not only between humanitarian organizations and their partners but
label: BODY

text: also with FSPs and other third parties involved in the delivery of assistance.
label: BODY

text: Establish an
label: BODY

text: information sharing
label: BODY

text: protocol specific to
label: BODY

text: CVA programming
label: BODY

text: Establish data
label: HH1

text: sharing agreements
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 9    This includes Data Protection Impact Assessments as well as other types of assessments that consider the potential risks, harms, and benefits of
label: BODY

text: a data management exercise. Learn more in this Guidance Note on Data Impact Assessments by the Centre for Humanitarian Data, ICRC, Privacy
label: BODY

text: International, and UN Global Pulse.
label: BODY

text: 10 Learn more in this Guidance Note on Data Incident Management by the Centre for Humanitarian Data and the Jackson Institute for Global Affairs at
label: BODY

text: Yale University.
label: BODY

text: Conduct data
label: BODY

text: impact assessments
label: BODY

text: for all CVA
label: BODY

text: interventions
label: BODY

text: Data impact assessments9 determine the expected risks, harms and benefits,
label: BODY

text: as well as privacy, data protection and/or human rights impacts of a data
label: BODY

text: management activity. An assessment informs the design and implementation
label: BODY

text: of data management activities in a way that maximizes benefits and minimizes
label: BODY

text: risks. The most common type of data impact assessment in CVA programmes
label: BODY

text: is a Data Protection Impact Assessment, which focuses explicitly on personal
label: BODY

text: data. If a CVA programme also generates large volumes of non-personal data,
label: BODY

text: organizations should try to expand on their standard assessment template to
label: BODY

text: also address risks, harms and benefits related to non-personal data.
label: BODY

text: Managing, tracking and communicating about data incidents requires standard
label: BODY

text: operating procedures for incident management10 and a central registry or log
label: BODY

text: that captures key details about the nature, severity, and resolution of each
label: BODY

text: incident. This will often include a mechanism for rectification and redress
label: BODY

text: through which beneficiaries can seek resolution of issues related to the
label: BODY

text: provision of CVA, including concerns about the management of their data.
label: BODY

text: While organizations are encouraged to establish their own data incident
label: BODY

text: management procedures, collective monitoring of incidents and sharing of
label: BODY

text: lessons learned via the CWG is important in the complex and interconnected
label: BODY

text: CVA data ecosystem.
label: BODY

text: Coordination structures such as a Cash Working Group can serve as a
label: BODY

text: common platform for monitoring collective progress and/or challenges
label: BODY

text: and opportunities for data responsibility. They can also support improved
label: BODY

text: coordination and decision-making  to advance data responsibility in CVA
label: BODY

text: delivery in a given context.
label: BODY

text: Introduce data
label: BODY

text: incident
label: BODY

text: management
label: BODY

text: procedures
label: BODY

text: Track issues and
label: HH1

text: progress on data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in
label: BODY

text: CVA through
label: BODY

text: coordination
label: BODY

text: structures
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in promoting data responsibility in the delivery of
label: BODY

text: cash and voucher assistance with the Centre via centrehumdata@un.org.

text: COLLABORATORS: CALP AND NORCAP/NORWEGIAN REFUGEE COUNCIL.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
